ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned so much about kids - the combination of hands-on work, especially in the daycare, and readings/lecture material was really great! Overall was a fun and light environment, and the assignments (journals) held you accountable for at least getting the jist of the readings.

I learned SO MUCH about children! Our course was split into three main themes: theory, curriculum, and policy. I felt I learned the most about theory, but the course did cover the other two themes in extensive detail. I also learned a surprising amount about myself as we had to reflect on our upbringing in the journals.
Child development theory, childcare policy, early childhood curriculum and more!
We learned different aspects of children, parents, and ECE educators as well as the development and relationships of these people.

I gained an extremely comprehensive understanding of various facets of Early Childhood Education (ECE), from curriculum to theory to policy. I also learned how to process observations and connect them with theory.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Weaknesses were just that timing was pretty poor - lecture would tend to go over and into the time that was supposed to be allotted for sections. Wasn't a huge deal, but could make things seem disorganized. Also, issues with the technology in the classroom could get very frustrating - slides would go down and wouldn't be on canvas, etc.

Strengths: Professors Close and Horwitz are both EXPERTS on kids, and it was such a privilege to hear their perspectives and learn from them.

Strengths: the professors were great, the observations helped ground our readings, and the guest lectures were very interesting

Weakness: sometimes we had technology troubles

The professors and guest speakers are all amazing! Each lecture is quite interesting and I was able to connect a lot of things learned from the class to my observations within the daycare and with the child I observed.
Discussion section at the end of the course was nice, although time didnt always allow for it.

Strengths: I really enjoyed the guest lectures, which offered extremely unique insights from professionals dealing with certain issues like Anti-Bias Education, speech pathology, and curriculum on the grounds. I thought the observations were extremely effective in learning theory on the ground.

Weaknesses: More organization in terms of lecture slides being uploaded onto Canvas.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, to anyone who wants to work with children in the future!
Absolutely, especially if you are interested in working with children or having children (or on the fence about having children).

Highly highly recommend! My favorite class I've taken at Yale by far - I was able to learn a ton in a very low stress setting and the professors are so experienced, knowledgeable, and passionate about the topic. It's also so fun to discuss and hear when others share about their own childhood experiences. Observing a daycare classroom was also a lot of fun.
If you are passionate about children, yes.
I cannot recommend this course enough. Any student will seriously be able to connect with the diverse and pertinent content.
Yep. Basically a guaranteed A. profs are so kind and gentle. if you're looking for a psych class for med school, this is the one.
